content: Nice puzzle, I like. But I work in power bussiness, and I ask myself if you can write "electrical current consumption" in place of "electrical current power". It's power (kW) that makes fuse blown and not consumption... ok, ok, it makes no changes about how pretty solving your puzzle was ;-)

God damn it.
I hate it when I fail validators because my input parsing crashes at
int[] toggles = Console.ReadLine().Split(' ').Select(int.Parse).ToArray();

https://prnt.sc/mt5sxf

This is not about the puzzle per se, but about the theme. SI unit for power is W (watts) and SI unit for electrical current is A (ampere). One should differentiate between them, they are not the same physical quantities. For example, the 1A electrical current through the equipment that is plugged to mains socket in US will produce only about half the power, when comparing to the same 1A in EU mains socket.

The stub is incorrect (the first 3 read should be in one single line, then use loopline for lines 2 & 3).
I would prefer the "The fuse will be blown if..." part to be in the main section (it's part of the goal of the problem). Not a huge fan of "Refer to the first two test cases...", this does not cost much to explain it properly (you could alternatively use a STATEMENT section in the stub).

As the puzzle got accepted anyway, I took the liberty to strighten the statement, the test cases and the stub generator. Power can't be measured in amps, when we are talking about ampers, then we are talking about electrical current.
Checked the current inputs have no space after line breaks. Which validator caused problem? Let me check again. Thanks

Thanks your constructive comment. There was an opposite argument saying that power is in W or kW while the fuse capacity is in A so that it does not make sense to directly compare the two.
I am assuming power consumption values of devices have been converted into the same unit A (formula varies according to local power supply standard) to allow for comparison and calculation. So comes the term "current consumption" instead of "power consumption".
I'm no expert in electricity or physics. I thought about alternative terms like "loading", but not quite sure the proper usage.
But anyway "consumed current" was a term included in the output. This one cannot be changed. All other descriptions can be amended for good reasons.

Validator 5, but I already updated it.
I still complain in the hope to get it right for future puzzles :P

This is honest question to downvoter. Do you think that the way how physics describes the essence of the nature is somehow flawed? I am not saying that it is absolutely and indisputably right, I'd really like to have the objections!

Thanks your comment. I know in convention there is a difference in units being used for power supply and electrical current. For simplicity here assumes the power consumption of electrical devices is translated into the same unit for current. As the experiment happens in the same room, the US or UK system does not affect the translation.
I welcome suggestion of additional statement explaining these physics properties, while not over-kill to make it become a physics lesson.

The stub is still wrong for lines 2 and 3, you should use loopline as the numbers are on one single line. It doesn't make any difference in C/C++ or Java (where operators that skip any kind of spaces are used), but it matters in some other languages.

This time tested successfully in python, php, pascal, js... should be ok
Thanks
